body:
Let's explore what a brand is, and what makes a strong brand.

 

Let's look at:

  • The difference between a strong and weak brand
  • How to keep a brand strong
  • Which parts of your business need to be involved in branding
title: What makes a strong brand?

body:
A company's brand is a series of promises made to customers about what they will deliver if the customer chooses them. 


For example, online takeaway website Just Eat promises to 'make food discovery exciting for everyone'.


Customers will build up an impression of the Just Eat brand through every interaction - from landing on their website to reading about a friend's experience on Facebook. Customers will ultimately be the judge on a companies ability to deliver on their promises.  


A strong brand will keep delivering on its promises and make customers feel so good that they come back again and again.


Simon Francis, founder of Flock Marketing Transformation, shares his thoughts on brands.
title: What is a brand?

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222515112" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
Although branding might seem like it is obsessing over superficial details,  it has a deep impact on customers and their willingness to part with their money for your products. 


Urban Massage, an online professional home massage service turned a complete stranger into their brand evangelist.
displayTitle: How does branding help you to make sales?

_items.body:
The subconscious brain thinks:

  • I feel achy. I'd love a massage
_items.title: Step 1: The trigger

_items.body:
The subconscious brain thinks: 

  • I could use my favourite beauty booking website or check out Urban Massage, the website I saw advertised on the train. It looked quite good and since it focuses on massage only it might be able to offer me something better. 


The branding magic is: 

  • Urban Massage's name communicated their expertise in a specific niche. Their messages and images caught my attention, stayed in my memory. 
  • This means that when I was ready to buy, their name popped into my head. Since the impression they left was positive (even though I can't remember the details of the poster), I look them through to the next phase of my journey by looking up their website.
_items.title: Step 2: Initial consideration
Step 3: Make a choice
_items.body:
My subconscious brain thinks:

  • The generic beauty website had stretched photos, so maybe they are not very professional and a bit outdated. Maybe their techniques would also be outdated and the therapists would be unprofessional. The whole experience could be awkward!
  • But, Urban Massage looks fresh and clean. The therapist will probably be optimistic and have good hygiene. The therapist will probably be professional and positive like the smiling lady in the photo wearing a white therapist coat.


The branding magic is:

  • Urban massage's careful choice of words and images on the website evoked positive feelings and assumptions about their service. The clarity and consistency of their message made me trust them more on their promises.

My subconscious brain thinks:

  • I feel like I'd have a good experience with Urban Massage. I feel like they will leave me feeling truly relaxed so I'm going to go with them.


The branding magic is:

  • The strong positive image which the brand created made me predict that I would be happier working with them. This is where feelings turn into hard cash!
_items.title: Step 4: Make an appointment

_items.body:
Then I go ahead and try out their services, and have a massage in my home.  It was an all-round good experience.

 

My subconscious brain thinks:

  • The therapist was professional, friendly and the experience was logistically easy. Urban Massage can be trusted to deliver on their promises. I'd use them again and recommend them to a friend.
_items.title: Step 5: Match the expectations to reality

title: How does branding help you to make sales?

body:
The two pillars of brand strength are brand awareness and brand image.


Brand awareness. How many customers think of your brand spontaneously and across how many product categories. 


Brand image. How positively and passionately customers feel about your brand. 


For example, Apple is a famously strong brand. It is very well known across multiple product categories (phones, tablets, laptops). It has many passionately positive customers (people who only buy iPhones and those who sleep outside Apple shops before new products get released).
displayTitle: How can you measure a brand's strength?
title: How can you measure a brand's strength?

body: What makes a strong brand and how do you measure it?

_items.title: Brand awareness: Depth
_items.body:
Many customers spontaneously think of your brand in a specific product category. 


Here are some measurement ideas.


In a survey, ask customers to list all the brands they can think of in your industry, for example, online food websites. See how many include your business in their list. 

Use social media monitoring tools like Brandwatch to measure how many people are talking about your company on social media (positively or negatively) and how many people can see those posts. 

Use the free Adwords Keyword Volume tool to see how many people are searching each month for your brand terms (rather than Googling non-branded keywords like online takeaway website).

_items.title: Brand awareness: Breadth
_items.body:
This is how many different product categories your product is remembered in.


Here are some measurement ideas.


A survey asking customers to list all the brands they can think of in different market niches. 


For example, Just Eat might ask which brand customers think of when they need to order:

  • Takeaway online
  • Food for a meeting 
  • Fine dining for a date at home 
  • Food to their hotel when they are abroad

This is how positively customers feel about your brand. 


Here are some measurement ideas.


In a survey, ask customers to score your brand out of 5 on:
  • Sincerity (down-to-earth, honest, wholesome, cheerful)
  • Excitement (daring, spirited, imaginative, up-to-date)
  • Competence (reliable, intelligent, successful)
  • Sophistication (upper-class, charming) 
  • Ruggedness (outdoorsy, tough) 
(Based on Jennifer Aaker’s model)


Track the proportion of your customers who return to your product again or choose other products in your brand range. This might be an indicator of how positively they feel about your brand.
_items.title: Brand image: Positivity
Brand image: Strength
_items.body:
The strength of a brand's image is reflected in how passionately customers feel about your brand. Beware, though, this could be a positive or negative response! 


Here is a measurement idea.


Observe how many customers are sharing your posts on social media, or are making spontaneous comments about your brand.

title: Brand awareness and image

displayTitle: How can you define your brand?
body:
Brand statements are useful summaries of the promises a brand is making. 


They should help you to make big and small decisions about your company - from which candidate to choose for a job to which jewellery your model should wear for a photo shoot. 


Here are three brand statements from prominent businesses.

_items.title: Just Eat
_items.body:
Just Eat offers more choice than anyone else – catering to every taste, mood, occasion and budget.


We’re making food discovery exciting for everyone – this is our new purpose, and what makes us leap out of bed every morning.

_items.title: Apple
_items.body:
1. We believe that we’re on the face of the Earth to make great products.
  2. We believe in the simple, not the complex.
  3. We believe that we need to own and control the primary technologies behind the products we make.
  4. We participate only in markets where we can make a significant contribution.
  5. We believe in saying no to thousands of projects so that we can really focus on the few that are truly important and meaningful to us.
  6. We believe in deep collaboration and cross-pollination of our groups, which allow us to innovate in a way that others cannot.
  7. We don’t settle for anything less than excellence in every group in the company, and we have the self-honesty to admit when we’re wrong and the courage to change.


Tim Cook, Apple CEO

1. We champion creative entrepreneurs

Every time you shop with us, you'll help support some of the UK's best small creative businesses (more than 5000 sell through our site — we call them our Partners).


2. We’re very picky

Each of our products are handpicked by our experts. We choose gifts that are unique, thoughtful and truly personal — not just personalised. That’s why with many of our products, you can choose the colour, font, style, material and add your own special message.


3. We pride ourselves on quality

High quality means a lot to us and our Partners. We want you to enjoy that ‘new love’ feeling for even longer, and give gifts that last.
_items.title: Not On The High Street

title: How can you define your brand?

body: A good brand statement should pass the following tests.
displayTitle: What makes a good brand statement?

_items.title: Could you use your brand statement to choose between two candidates applying for a job at your startup?

Are your brand values unique?
Do they capture how you are different from competitors?
Could you use your brand statement to design your website?

Are what you are promising to customers the things that are important to them? 
After all, you are not running the business for your own interests!

title: What makes a good brand statement?

body:
The 4P's - product, price, place and promotion - are the channels a company uses to communicate its brand values to customers.


While it important to seize every opportunity to share your brand promises with customers, the best way by far is to build a strong brand and deliver an amazing product.


That way they won't have to believe that you will delight them - they will know! And, they will likely come back and tell others about you.


Actions speak louder than words and customer recommendations speak louder than your promises.

_items.body:
This category includes your company's name, logo, packaging, website images and designs. 


It also includes all aspects of your customer support. Think about what questions they will ask. 


Will they call customers by their first name or surname? How well trained will they be?
_items.title: Product
Price
_items.body: Does your product's price say 'bargain for the masses' or 'exclusive luxury'?

Where will your product be for sale?


Which social channels will you choose? Inspiring Instagram or serious LinkedIn? 


Will you be selling on Amazon's bargain marketplace or Etsy's creative marketplace? 


Does the customer's experience on your website reflect your values - luxury, creativity or the personal touch?
_items.title: Place

_items.body:
What language do you use in your adverts and customer emails? Formal or cheeky? Inspiring or pragmatic? 


What imagery do you choose?

What do your models look like?

How are they styled and what do they wear?
_items.title: Promotion

title: Communicate your brand to customers

It's a logo and symbol to help differentiate you from other providers.
A brand is a marketing strategy.
It helps employees and customers understand what the company and the product stand for.

title: T4C1Q2 What makes a strong brand?

body:
Brand touchpoints fall under one of the 4Ps.


Match the touchpoints with the approppriat 4P category.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Price, place, product and promotion are all ways you can communicate your brand values to your customers.

_items.text: Your name, logo, packaging, customer service style and delivery methods
How much customers have to pay
The look and feel of the website where you sell your products
The marketing events you choose to sponsor to raise your profile

title: T4C1Q3 Communicating your brand

body:
A brand is the series of promises you make to your customers about what they can expect if they choose you. Make them feel good! 


Strong brands are ones that many customers know about and link positively and passionately with more than one of their needs. 


You can use the 4Ps of product, price, place, and promotion to communicate those brand promises to your customer. 


Ultimately, the way to get customers to trust you most is to have a brilliant product that works and that customers tell other people about. 


Actions speak louder than words and customer recommendations speak louder than the promises you make.
title: What makes a strong brand? Let's wrap it up
